have you ever wanted to stay young a

Long Live mutant so we started to change

Gene called daap 2 doubled the lifespan
of the little worm so you can see in
black after a month they're very

really really interesting it says that

the daff 2 hormone receptor is very

made our discoveries with little

and they also the common precursor also
gave rise to people so maybe it's

just like any population most of the

what they found was that there were

those are hints suggesting that humans

and when they do it's not as severe so

so it suggests that if we could you know

Aging how could that work well it turns

that encode proteins that protect the

on is by a gene regulator protein called
foxo so in adap 2 mutant you see that I
have the X drawn here to the receptor
the receptor isn't working as well under
those conditions the foxo protein in
blue has gone into the nucleus that
little compartment there in the middle
of the cell and it's sitting down on a
gene binding to it well you see one gene
there are lots of genes actually that
bind a foxo and it's just sitting on one
of them so foxo turns on a lot of genes
and the genes it turns on includes
antioxidant genes genes I call carrot
Giver genes whose protein products um
actually help other proteins to function
well to fold correctly and function
correctly and it can also escort them to

are are more active in these animals and
the immune system is more active and
many of these different genes we've
shown actually contribute to the long
lifespan of the daff 2 mutant so it's
really interesting these animals have
within them the latent capacity to live
much long longer than they normally do
they have the ability to protect
themselves from many kinds of damage
which we think makes them live
longer so what about the normal worm
well when the daff 2 receptor is active
then it triggers a series of events that
prevent foxo from getting into the
nucleus where the DNA is so it can't
turn the genes on that's how it works
that's why we don't see the long life

what good is this for the worm well we
think that the insulin and igf1 hormones
are hormones that are particularly
active under favorable conditions in the

of nutrients you can store the food use

example having limited food
supply um and that we think is
registered by the animal as a danger
signal a signal that things are not okay
and that it should roll out protective
capacity so it activates foxo foxo goes
to the DNA and that triggers the
expression of these genes that improve
the ability of the cell to protect
itself and repair itself and that's why
we think the animals live longer so you
can think of foxo as being like um a

here for how we think this life
extension ability exists now the really
cool thing about foxo is that there are
different forms of it we all have foxo

foxo exactly the same form of the foxo
gene just like we all have eyes but we
some of us have blue eyes and some of us

that's the case all over the world as

okay are there differences in the type

maybe if we tweak it a little bit we can
we can increase um the Health and
